contentrichtext.text: {{About||the 2002 film|Tiramisu (film)}} {{Infobox prepared food | name = Tiramisu | image = [[File:Tiramisu with cholocate sauce at Ferrara in Little Italy, New York City.jpg|200px]] | imagesize = | caption = | alternate_name = | country = Italy | region = | creator = | course = [[Dessert]] | served = | main_ingredient = [[Ladyfinger (biscuit)|Savoiardi]], [[egg yolk]]s, [[mascarpone]], [[Cocoa solids|cocoa]] | variations = | calories = | other = }} '''Tiramisu''' ({{IPA-it|tiɾamiˈsu|}}, [[Italian language|Italian]] spelling: ''Tiramisù''; lit. "pick me up" or "lift me up") is an [[Italian cuisine|Italian]] dessert. It is made of [[Ladyfinger (biscuit)|ladyfingers]] (Italian: ''Savoiardi'') dipped in coffee, layered with a whipped mixture of [[egg yolk]]s and [[mascarpone cheese]], and flavored with [[Cocoa solids|cocoa]].<ref name="tiramisu recipe">{{cite episode |episodelink=http://www.rai.tv/dl/RaiTV/programmi/media/ContentItem-509100b3-1428-4109-9e43-73c6ef9c4568.html#p= |series=TG2 Eat Parade |network=RAI |date=31 August 2012 |number=700 |language=Italian}}</ref> The recipe has been adapted into many varieties of [[puddings]], [[cakes]] and other [[desserts]]. ==History== There is some debate regarding the origin of Tiramisu. Accounts by Carminantonio Iannaccone and Nathan Lopez (as researched and written about by ''The Washington Post'') establish the creation of Tiramisu by him on 24 December 1969 in Via Sottotreviso while he was head chef at [[Treviso]], near [[Venice]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Piedigrotta: History | url = http://www.piedigrottabakery.com/subpages/history.html | accessdate = 14 March 2010}} </ref><ref name="jane black">{{cite news | date = 10 July 2007 | first = Jane | last = Black | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/10/AR2007071000327.html | title = The Trail of Tiramisu | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | accessdate = 11 July 2007}} </ref> [[File:Tiramisu closeup, August 2006.jpg|thumb|right|Layers of a serving of Tiramisu.]] Alternatively, it may have originated as a variation of another layered dessert, ''[[Zuppa Inglese]]''.<ref name="history of tiramisu">{{cite web|title=History of tiramisù |url=http://www.annamariavolpi.com/page38.html |accessdate=16 August 2010}}</ref> It is mentioned in Giovanni Capnist's 1983 cookbook ''I Dolci Del Veneto'',<ref>{{cite book | title = I Dolci Del Veneto | first = Giovanni | last = Capnist | isbn = 88-7021-239-4 | year = 1983}} </ref> while ''Merriam-Webster's Online Dictionary'' gives 1982 as the first mention of the dessert.<ref>{{cite web | title = Tiramisu | work = Merriam-Webster's Online Dictionary | url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tiramisu | accessdate = 14 March 2010}} </ref> Other sources report the creation of the cake to have originated in the city of [[Siena]].<ref>Francesco Soletti, Ettore Toscani ''L'Italia del caffè'', 2004, p. 110.</ref> Some confectioners were said to have created it in honour of [[Cosimo III]] on the occasion of his visit to the country. The translation of the name Italian tiramisù (tirami sù) means "pick-me-up" (metaphorically, "make me happy"). This may refer to the [[caffeine]] in the espresso and effect of cocoa used in the recipe. ==Preparation== [[File:Tvarohové tiramisu 5.jpg|thumb|right|Arranging a layer of Savoiardi biscuits]] Tiramisu is a layered dessert, consisting of alternating layers of coffee-soaked ''Savoiardi'' biscuits and sweet mixture of mascarpone cheese, eggs and sugar. To prepare the biscuit layer, the ''Savoiardi'' are soaked in [[espresso]] or strong coffee. For the mascarpone cheese layer, a mixture of egg yolks and sugar is first prepared, to which the mascarpone cheese is then added. This mixture is spread over the coffee-soaked biscuits. More layers are added and the dessert is finally topped with a dusting of cocoa powder.<ref name="tiramisu recipe"/> Countless variations for Tiramisu exist. Some cooks use other cakes or sweet, yeasted breads, such as ''[[panettone]]'', in place of ladyfingers.<ref>''Larousse Gastronomique'', New York: Clarkson Potter Publishers, 2001, pp. 1214.</ref> Other cheese mixtures are used as well, some containing raw eggs, and others containing no eggs at all. [[Marsala wine]] can be added to the recipe, but other liquors are frequently substituted for it in both the coffee and the cheese mixture, including dark rum, [[Madeira wine|Madeira]], [[port (wine)|port]], [[brandy]] or [[Irish Cream]] such as [[Bailey's]]. ==See also== * [[Charlotte (dessert)|Charlotte]] * [[Cheesecake]] * [[Opera cake]] * [[Profiterole]] * [[Trifle]] {{cookbook|Tiramisù}} {{commons|Tiramisu}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Cakes}} [[Category:Italian desserts]] [[Category:Custard desserts]] [[Category:Cakes]] [[Category:Coffee dishes]]
